title: How to Understand Alibaba’s Latest Shopping Trip
text:
The imminent retirement of co-founder Jack Ma hasn’t dimmed the ambitions of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding . BABA 0.62%

On Friday—just days before Mr. Ma steps down as its executive chairman—Alibaba struck two deals with a new partner: NetEase, China’s largest game publisher after Tencent Holdings . TCEHY -0.05% Alibaba will buy Kaola, NetEase’s e-commerce business, for $2 billion. And together with Mr. Ma’s private-equity firm Yunfeng Capital, it will also invest $700 million in the gaming company’s music business in return for a minority stake. Mr. Ma is due to retire from the company on Tuesday, his 55th birthday.

Alibaba likely has its eyes on old rivals with these deals.

Kaola is an online platform that sells imported goods such as cosmetics and baby formula. It is the largest player in so-called cross-border e-commerce behind Alibaba’s Tmall Global. Greater scale—the two together make up more than half of the market in China, according to data research firm Analysys—will help lower costs.

China’s government campaign to regulate “daigou,” a popular practice in which middlemen buy goods from abroad to sell them back home, will probably drive more sales to officially sanctioned cross-border e-commerce sites like Kaola.

Alibaba got a good price for the website: 0.8 times this year’s sales, according to Morgan Stanley. That is probably because the unprofitable platform has mostly been a drag for NetEase. Increasingly, it had to compete head on with Alibaba, which has ramped up its market share in cross-border e-commerce in recent years. For Alibaba, buying Koala is also a pre-emptive move to prevent its major e-commerce rivals, JD.com and Pinduoduo—both backed by Tencent—from snapping it up first.

While the Kaola deal defends Alibaba’s lead in e-commerce, the music transaction is about patching up an area of weakness. Tencent’s three online music platforms—Kugou, QQ Music and Kuwo—have combined monthly active users of 652 million, far ahead of NetEase’s 113 million and Alibaba’s 20 million, according to Bernstein. Alibaba’s infusion of capital probably won’t help them unseat Tencent soon, but it could at least keep them in the game.

Mr. Ma may be leaving the behemoth he helped to found 20 years ago, but the old rivalries live on. Investors can expect more such deal making from Alibaba.

Write to Jacky Wong at JACKY.WONG@wsj.com
description: The imminent retirement of co-founder Jack Ma hasn’t dimmed the ambitions of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba. The company’s recent deals seem aimed at keeping old rivals at bay.
